title: Security flaw: Settings accessible after canceling OS authentication prompt
content:
When accessing about:logins, Firefox prompts for system authentication (Primary password or master password). However, if the user cancels the prompt twice, the password manager still opens and displays all saved logins without authentication.

This behavior bypasses the intended security check and could pose a risk, especially in shared or public machines
creator: eng.fouadhany

title: Sync with Two-Step Authentication protected Google account failed
content:
I discovered that I cannot sync with my google account protected from 2FA.

In detail:

  1. Numbered list item showing something went wrong page when I am trying to login from (about:preferences#sync);
  2. Numbered list item Login successful with another account not protected by 2FA

Note that:

  1. Numbered list item cookie allowed;
  2. Numbered list item using newest version;
  3. Numbered list item protection set to standard;
  4. Numbered list item tried to reinstall firefox

but none of them are successful.

I have also confirm that:

  1. Numbered list item the account is able to sign in from other platform from mozilla(it's the account I'm using now)

title: Firefox won't load some websites but will load others, and must be refreshed multiple times to get Google Workspace apps like Drive and the Calendar to fully load.
content:
Yesterday (5/19), I noticed that Firefox wouldn't load certain websites - specifically, Facebook and my credit union after I tried to login, as well as some commercial websites I use for work, such as Claude.ai. YouTube videos did not play well either - they started buffering after a minute or two. I also noticed that when I was logged into my Google Workspace, apps like Drive and the Calendar had to be refreshed multiple times to get them to fully load - and even then, sometimes that didn't work. Yet other sites would load and function just fine.

After working with Microsoft support yesterday to determine if it was a Windows problem (it doesn't appear to be), I started checking to see if it was a browser issue, especially since I can access everything I need to just fine on Microsoft Edge. I have tried clearing my cache, refreshing Firefox, reinstalling Firefox, and completing a full virus scan on my PC (no issues detected), but nothing has worked and the same problems continue.

Any ideas? (Please note that I have limited tech troubleshooting skills. I am an ordinary user, not a developer.)

Many thanks.

title: Firefox browser using huge amounts of CPU on Linux Mint 22.1 Xia base: Ubuntu 24.04 noble
content:
I have been using Firefox for many years now and I have always been greatly satisfied with its stability, performance and features. However with the last couple of releases something has changed. The number of tabs I keep open and what they are connected to have changed very little over the years. The CPU utilization has never been much but now it has become huge - utilizing multiple CPU cores and running them at 100% whether I am using the browser or not. I have gone thru each individual tab/web page removing it, waiting for a period of time and them re-adding it assuming this was a website coding issue. Nothing changed. So I gave up and move 98% of my web browsing to another browser (Opera) - moving one website at a time until what was left on Firefox was 11 tabs. Finally the CPU utilization went away. I got the latest Firefox version update today, installed it and now Firefox has changed behavior yet again. Those same 11 tabs will not use any CPU as long as I keep Firefox open and visible on screen, but if I minimize the Firefox window it immediately jumps up in CPU utilization. This makes no sense to me.

What adds to all this frustration is I am running on a system76 Thelio desktop. While extremely fast they have a known issue with their somewhat loud CPU cooling fan kicking in too fast when high CPU utilization occurs. Firefox never used to cause the fans to run but now the latest couple of versions cause the fan to run continuously.

Here is a paste from "top" showing the top 2 cpu processes - both from Firefox and the browser is minimized: 

416154 greeves   20   0 3796844 612012 260196 R 109.6   0.9 147:49.17 firefox-bin                              416394 greeves   20   0 3537408 822456 130500 R  89.7   1.3 146:40.46 Web Content  
 My apologies if I have run on with too much info that is of no help.  If anyone has any ideas it would be appreciated and I would be happy to test.  FYI, my OS is up to date, Firefox is up to date, BIOS is up to date, I have restarted Firefox many times and I have rebooted several times.  I thought Mint might be the issue so I loaded Pop-Os and tried it with the same results.  Btw neither Opera or Brave shows the problem.  However I would prefer to use Firefox as I really like the features - especially how it handles tabs and grouping them.

Thanks in advance for any help!
creator: greeves7

title: Serious problem with your latest update
content:
Hi,

I’m writing you as a very annoyed, frustrated and seriously pissed off user.

I’m a senior lecturer at De Montfort University, Leicester, and have been using Mozilla since 2020/21 on my university account, since I don’t want Google Chrome and Microsoft Edge is user-unfriendly shit. Now, my Mozilla account was registered via DMU (technically set up by the university’s ITMS) to run as my default browser, which opened automatically logged-in and ready to go each time I started the computer. This is how it has worked for the last four years and through many, many updates… until yesterday.

Since the last update on Monday, May 19th, all my access records, settings and bookmarks have been completely wiped off. In fact, it appears that my university-registered account has been wiped in its entirety. Strangely, Mozilla Firefox is still my default browser but only opens with a standard default window. More importantly, I was no longer able to log into my account, as if my account no longer exists… which also means that all my bookmarks and links to important websites within DMU and externally have all disappeared. It will take me at least 1 week (if I focus on nothing else) to find and restore them.

So, how was such a car crash of an update actually possible? Please note that ITMS at DMU is placing the blame and responsibility of this fuckup squarely on you. Furthermore, why was this update actually necessary? Mozilla Firefox was until yesterday a far superior browser in terms of user-friendliness and style compared to Google Chrome, Microsoft Edge or Apple Safari. Now it’s little more than a cheap, equally flawed Microsoft Edge copycat both in style and user-unfriendliness!

But even worse, I now find out that Mozilla like all those "revolutionary, democratizing" tech companies cannot even be bothered to be accessible for contact when in need for support. Anyway, I would like to know how your update could wipe out my account and all the bookmarks just like that, as if they never existed in the first place. And how do I get my my original settings back?

Very disappointing.

Regards,

Markus
creator: markus.wohlfeil

title: Firefox Translation Icon Not Appearing for English Page
content:
Hello,

I’ve noticed that Firefox does not show the translation icon in the toolbar for a webpage, even though the page is in English. When I manually go to "Application Menu" → "Translate Page…", I receive the message: "Translation is not available for this page - Sorry, this language is not yet supported." However, if I click on "Change source language" and manually set it to English, the translation works correctly. It seems like Firefox is not detecting the language of the page automatically, and as a result, the translation feature does not appear unless I manually intervene. The issue occurred on this page: "https://mantisbt.org/docs/master/en-US/Developers_Guide/html-desktop/#dev.contrib.submit.before".

I also looked for a way to report this issue, but I only found a form for reporting incorrectly translated words here: "https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSdoRWnsHX6vVnGIRyLi4Kl-p0GrmeVIioqWsTz3aVTRfLScng/viewform". There doesn't seem to be an option to report entire sites where the translation does not work at all.

I'm using: Firefox Desktop 138.0.4 (64 bit) on Windows 10 22H2. Thanks for your help.

title: How to get a refund from Airtel payment bank?
content: To get a refund from Airtel Payments Bank, you'll need to contact their customer support. You can call them at 121 or 09531-163911" or use the Airtel Thanks app to request a refund. Alternatively, you can visit the Airtel website and check their "Help" or "Support" section for guidance. Provide details like your phone number, the amount recharged, and the transaction date to facilitate the refund process.
creator: Rahul064315

title: How can I refund my Airtel wrong recharge?
content: To request a refund for a wrong recharge on Airtel, follow these steps: Contact Customer Support: Call Airtel customer care at 121 or 0953116-3911. * use the Airtel app for assistance.
